Enhancing Spatial Knowledge With Discrete Euclidean Virtual 3D Display Interfaces: Design Options

Tiffany N. Saffell Wright State University , Dayton, Ohio, USA , Herbert A. Colle Wright State University , Dayton, Ohio, USA Correspondencecollewsu@yahoo.com
, Ian M. Bock Wright State University , Dayton, Ohio, USA & Lisa J. Douglas Wright State University , Dayton, Ohio, USA
Pages 48-60
Accepted author version posted online: 24 Jun 2011
Published online:05 Dec 2011
  • Download citation
  • https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.568853
In this articleClose

    • 2. EXPERIMENT 1
      • 3. EXPERIMENT 2
        • 4. DESIGN IMPLICATIONS
          • References

          Articles

          Enhancing Spatial Knowledge With Discrete Euclidean Virtual 3D Display Interfaces: Design Options

          • Full Article
          • Figures & data
          • References
          • Citations
          • Metrics
          • Reprints & Permissions
          • PDF

          Abstract

          Getting lost within Internet applications has been addressed with limited success by treating hypertext navigation as analogous to spatial navigation. One alternative for shopping-specific interfaces is to create discrete virtual three-dimensional (3D) Euclidian spaces for web navigation. Equivalent configural spatial knowledge acquisition was obtained from searches in discrete HTML Euclidian environments and comparable desktop 3D virtual environments (Couture, Colle, & Reid, 2005, International Journal of Human–Computer Interaction). However, between-store spatial knowledge was not optimal for both discrete HTML and continuous desktop virtual environments. Also, walking longer distances between stores is undesirable. These issues are addressed with two design options. In Experiment 1, better between-store spatial knowledge was acquired in linear and clustered arrangements of adjacent stores than with hallway travel between stores. In Experiment 2, map menu teleportation, selecting a store teleportation destination from a map menu, did not spatially disorient participants. Design implications for several domains were discussed.

          1. INTRODUCTION

          Internet environments consist of multiple sources of information, which users or visitors search to find sources of interest. The process of finding relevant sources of information is called navigation. In the document Recommended Policies and Guidelines for Federal Public Websites (Interagency Committee on Government Information, 2004), navigation was defined as “the means by which a visitor can navigate the content of a website. Navigation usually consists of a collection of links to sections and subsections of a website” (p. 45). In these applications, users or visitors have been found to face a memory problem of getting back to a needed site after having traveled to additional sites in search of additional information. “Getting lost” has been identified as a problem in website navigation (Helander, 2000; H. Kim & Hirtle, 1995; Otter & Johnson, 2000).

          1.1. Web Space Versus Euclidean Space

          The prevention of users or visitors from getting lost while navigating websites has focused on using the metaphor that website navigation of irregular nodes and links is analogous to spatial navigation in physical space, but the adequacy of this metaphor has been questioned because of differences in cognitive and memory processes used in the two environments (Boechler, 2001; Dillon, McKnight, & Richardson, 1990; Farris, Jones, & Elgin, 2002). Couture, Colle, and Reid (2005) implemented a solution by constructing Euclidean spaces out of hypertext nodes and links, creating a discrete version of a virtual environment using static images of perspective views at each hypertext node. Thus, website navigation was directly analogous to spatial navigation in an equivalent physical space. Euclidean hypertext networks are particularly useful for content structured domains such as online shopping because semantic content information of the domain (girls' clothes, shoes, housewares, etc.) is correlated with spatial locations in physical stores. It is also potentially useful because it could facilitate positive transfer from physical environment shopping to online shopping. People who already have mental models of a domain such as shopping could capitalize on these inherited visualizations of a mental model or frozen metaphors (Chen, 1998; Stanney, Chen, Wedell, & Breaux, 2003).

          1.2. Spatial Knowledge Acquisition

          In web spaces, not being lost typically means being able to return to a previously visited site node after leaving it and continuing to search for other information. More generally, people can remember where to find a particular site node with the desired information.

          Geographic spaces are large-scale physical or virtual spaces that are too large to be viewed completely from a single viewpoint. They can be “experienced only by integration of perceptual experiences over space and time through memory and reasoning, or through the use of small-scale models such as maps” (Mark, Freksa, Hirtle, Lloyd, & Tversky, 1999, p. 748). In geographic spaces, not being lost can be the result of the operation of several different cognitive processes and memory representations. Spatial knowledge has been commonly categorized into three different types: landmark, route, and configural or survey knowledge (Siegel & White, 1975). Landmark knowledge refers to knowledge of important objects or environmental characteristics in an environment. Route spatial knowledge refers to knowledge of pathways to follow to get from one location to another. It appears to be declarative knowledge based on propositions with spatial referents such as turn left or turn right. Thus, website navigation appears to be most related to landmark or route knowledge. Declarative knowledge refers to the acquisition and use of episodic or semantic/conceptual memory systems, which has been attributed to activity in hippocampal and related medial temporal lobe structures (Squire, 1987, 2004).

          However, in geographic spaces people can get from Point A to Point B without knowing explicit routes to traverse on paths, roads, or hallways. They can know the angular direction of Point B when at Point A and can move in that direction. Spatial knowledge of the direction and distances among landmarks in an environment is called configural spatial knowledge, which is thought to be the most complex type of spatial knowledge. Users spatially comprehend an environment when they understand the spatial relationships and remember the locations of important landmarks. Configural spatial knowledge refers to the memory representations underlying this spatial comprehension. Although Siegel and White (1975) argued that landmark, route, and configural knowledge were learned in sequence, more recent research has shown that configural spatial knowledge can be acquired rapidly and concurrently with the acquisition of route knowledge (e.g., Colle & Reid, 1998; Gillner & Mallot, 1998; Montello, 1998). The accuracy of directional pointing judgments and of sketch maps of an environment have been used in human research as converging measures of configural spatial knowledge (Douglas & Colle, 2010).

          Although configural spatial knowledge measurement is theoretically consistent with allocentric neuroscience models of spatial memory, comparing the two is not straightforward. Geographical models of large-scale spaces are still sketchy, and descriptions of relevant brain processes are still controversial. Allocentric spatial memory, not just declarative memory, has been attributed to activity in the hippocampus and related structures (O'Keefe & Nadel, 1978). However, other brain structures have also been implicated (Shrager, Bayley, Bontempi, Hopkins, & Squire, 2007; Shrager, Kirwan, & Squire, 2008). Likewise, Ungerleider and Mishkin (1982) identified the dorsal visual pathway “as specialized for spatial processing (locating where an object is)” (p. 549). However, more recent research has argued that the dorsal visual pathway is specialized vision for action as opposed to the ventral pathway's specialization as vision for perception (Goodale, 2008; Goodale & Milner, 1992). The parietal cortex also produces spatial neglect when damaged, but it is typically attributed to a shift in spatial attention. Regardless of these uncertainties of brain location, however, directional pointing and sketch maps have been used as behavioral measures of configural spatial knowledge in human geographic spatial research.

          1.3. Discrete Euclidean 3D Perspective View Interfaces

          Importantly, research by Couture et al. (2005) found that configural spatial knowledge, spatial comprehension, obtained with only a few hypertext nodes that show perspective views of an environment was equivalent to the configural spatial knowledge obtained from a typical 3D virtual environment with continuous movement and optical flow of images. Previously, it had been proposed that 3D perspective viewing of virtual environments (Apple QuickTime) could be used for shopping applications (Howes, Miles, Payne, Mitchell, & Davies, 2001). Although video capabilities such as these are commonly available, they still demand considerable resources and throughput capability. A discrete hypertext Euclidean approach demands fewer resources. Couture et al.'s results suggest that at least for applications such as online shopping, the problem of getting lost can be solved by focusing on the development of more efficient techniques that utilized the capabilities of human spatial memory and cognition.

          1.4. Structuring an Environment to Enhance Spatial Comprehension

          Creating a discrete Euclidean space is not sufficient for completely solving the online shopping problem of getting lost or for obtaining an optimally desirable online shopping interface. The problem is not solved completely, because people also get lost when traveling in physical space. Lynch (1960) argued that physical environments should be designed to be what he called legible, easy to spatially comprehend. If people comprehend the relevant spatial relationships, they can use this configural spatial knowledge to travel from one place to another. In online shopping, however, the problem can be solved more readily than it can in physical environments by designing discrete virtual Euclidean environments in which people are less likely to get lost. No brick-and-mortar structures need to be modified to create these design changes.

          Colle and Reid (1998, 2000, 2003) have found that after people experience a large-scale environment of several rooms, they readily acquire good configural spatial knowledge for sets of objects that were located in the same room, but they have more difficulty acquiring configural spatial knowledge of the relative location of objects when two objects were in different rooms, which Colle and Reid called the room effect. In their experiments, people explored the virtual environments by finding the objects in one room and then using a hallway to get to objects in the next room. Couture et al. (2005) found an equivalent room effect for their 9–45° discrete Euclidean architecture when users shopped electronically. A single room is not likely to be sufficient for most shopping applications, but shoppers spatial knowledge would be improved if an architectural design could be found that reduced the room effect by improving between-room spatial knowledge.

          A possible design option for reducing the room effect is to eliminate the need to use hallways to travel from store to store. Structurally, stores could be arranged abutting each other so that as shoppers leave one store through a doorway they enter directly into another store. Colle and Reid (2000, 2003) have proposed that it is the structure of rooms that allows the spatial locations of objects within them to be learned so readily. They found that direct line-of-sight viewing was not responsible for the room effect, as removal of intervening walls between rooms did not improve configural spatial knowledge to the level of within room spatial knowledge acquisition (Colle & Reid, 2003). Therefore, it was suspected that structural features were responsible for the room effect. Going from room to room via hallways creates different spatial frames of reference for each room. However, it is possible that a single spatial frame of reference could be maintained by people if they went directly from one room to the next room. Experiment 1 tests this hypothesis by comparing spatial knowledge obtained when hallways were used to move from store to store with spatial knowledge obtained when hallways were not used and participants went directly from one store to the next.

          Eliminating hallways leaves the issue of store configuration. Robertson et al. (2000) used a linear configuration of rooms for their 3D Task Gallery interface for document retrieval, suggesting that this configuration would be easier to learn and comprehend. However, they did not experimentally compare their linear configuration with a nonlinear one. Experiment 1 addresses this issue by comparing configural spatial knowledge acquisition obtained from linear and nonlinear configurations of stores. Design flexibility would be enhanced if spatial knowledge acquisition was comparable for linear and nonlinear configurations of stores.

          1.5. Map Menu Teleportation

          Eliminating hallways creates another design advantage. It reduces the distances or number of steps that people have to “walk” to go from store to store. Hedman (2003) argued that long walks are undesirable for people such as online shoppers who typically are visitors and not users whose primary job is shopping. However, there are likely to be limitations on how many adjacent stores (without hallways) can be used without degrading spatial knowledge acquisition. Therefore, an alternative method of between store transportation, teleportation, was evaluated in Experiment 2. It evaluated a spatially organized teleportation technique called map menu teleportation. Teleportation allows a spatial viewpoint to be moved instantly to any spatial location in the environment, usually a large movement. Typical unorganized teleportation has been found to degrade spatial knowledge acquisition (Bakker, Passenier, & Werkoven, 2003; Couture et al., 2005; Ruddle, Howes, Payne, & Jones, 2000). Experiment 2 evaluated if this disorientation could be ameliorated by having shoppers select a teleportation destination by selecting the location from a menu which accurately represented the Euclidean store locations. Used in this way, teleportation may be related to map-controlled teleoperation, which is described in the Discussion section.

          2. EXPERIMENT 1

          This experiment addressed the design option of eliminating hallways. Two different experimental issues were evaluated. First, the issue of whether traveling from store to store without using hallways would improve between-store configural spatial knowledge acquisition was assessed. If so, an interaction between hallways versus no hallways and the room effect would be expected. The second issue is whether the configuration of stores matters, when hallways are not used. Two different configurations of stores were used. In the clustered configuration, stores were grouped close together using a roughly circular arrangement. In the linear configuration, stores were arranged in a straight line. Between-store and within-store spatial knowledge was evaluated for all three of these layout conditions. Configural spatial knowledge was assessed using the same configural spatial measures used by Couture et al. (2005).

          2.1. Method

          Participants

          Seventy-two Wright State University introductory psychology students with a mean age of 19.5 (SD = 1.13) received course credit for participating. Ages ranged from 17 to 36. Along with demographic information, all participants reported previous experience with navigation and video games. Navigation and video game experience results mirrored the results found in Couture et al. (2005). Male and female participants (40 men, 32 women) did not differ in their experience with online shopping (men: M = 2.60, women: M = 2.43, where 1 = very little and 7 = very much), F(1, 60) = 0.013, MSE = 2.43, p > .05. Neither did male and female participants differ on online shopping enjoyment (men: M = 4.42, women: M = 4.03, where 1 = very negative and 7 = very positive), F(1, 60) = 0.695, MSE = 3.06, p > .05.

          However, as Couture et al. found, male and female participants rated themselves differently on action video game experience and how good they were at finding their way around a new place. Male participants reported playing more action video games than female participants (men: M = 5.33, women: M = 2.50, where 1 = very seldom and 7 = very often), F(1, 60) = 49.94, MSE = 2.71, p < .0001. They were also more confident at finding their way around a new location (men: M = 5.23, women: M = 3.78, where 1 = not good at all and 7 = very good), F(1, 60) = 12.49, MSE = 2.71, p < .01. In addition, we found that men reported having more general computer experience than women, F(1, 60) = 10.72, MSE = 1.74, p = .01 (men: M = 5.47, women: M = 4.75, where 1 = very little experience and 7 = very much experience). Although these demographic gender differences existed, gender did not interact with any of the experimental manipulations on the performance measures. Therefore, no gender differences are reported in the results. All participants reported having normal visual acuity or vision correct to normal with eyeglasses or contact lenses.

          2.2. 3D Online Environments

          Layouts and objects

          The three environmental configurations (hallway, cluster, and linear) are shown in Figure 1. In the hallway configuration (top layout in Figure 1), the three stores were connected by a complex hallway. The layout was identical to the layout used by Couture et al. (2005). Access from one store to the next was obtained by leaving the store and traversing the hallway to get to the next store. In the linear and cluster environments, however, participants could directly travel from store to store without having to use a hallway. In the linear configuration (bottom left layout in Figure 1), the three stores were abutted end to end so that the three stores had a roughly straight-line shape. In the cluster configuration (bottom right layout in Figure 1), the three stores were arranged in a circular configuration so that each store abutted the other two stores.

          FIG. 1. Environment layout and locations of target objects. Note. Dots represent viewpoint locations used in hypertext displays. Top, bottom-left, and bottom-right layouts were used in the hallways, linear, and clustered conditions, respectively. A = armchair; C = couch; N = nightstand; CM = copy machine; SR = stereo; T = TV; F = refrigerator; SV = stove; W = washing machine.

          Display full size

          FIG. 1. Environment layout and locations of target objects. Note. Dots represent viewpoint locations used in hypertext displays. Top, bottom-left, and bottom-right layouts were used in the hallways, linear, and clustered conditions, respectively. A = armchair; C = couch; N = nightstand; CM = copy machine; SR = stereo; T = TV; F = refrigerator; SV = stove; W = washing machine.

          As shown in Figure 1, each environmental configuration consisted of the same three stores: an appliance store, a consumer electronics store, and a furniture store. Each store contained three objects from one of the three categories: appliances (refrigerator, stove, and washing machine), consumer electronics (television, stereo, and copy machine) and furniture (couch, armchair, and nightstand). Objects were each placed against one of the four walls in each rectangular-shaped store.

          Online page construction and movement controls

          Online shopping environments were created using the procedures described in detail by Couture et al. (2005), except that only their Web 9–45° nodal HTML structure for the discrete Euclidean space was used. There were nine viewpoint locations in each store, represented by the nine dots per store in Figure 1. At each viewpoint location the user's point of view could by rotated by 45° increments to create eight viewpoint orientations at that viewpoint location. For each viewpoint location and orientation combination, an HTML web page was created. For this experiment, each HTML page was displayed by Microsoft Internet Explorer version 5.5. Each HTML page showed an image of a 3D perspective view of the shopping environment, taken from the appropriate viewpoint location and viewpoint orientation. The 3D perspective views were obtained from a 3D virtual environment, which was developed using the Morfit 3D graphics engine (3Dstate, available at http://www.3dstate.com). Web page images were obtained by taking screenshots from the corresponding viewpoint locations and viewpoint orientations in the Morfit 3D graphics environment and editing them to fit into web pages. Horizontal and vertical geometric fields of view were 90° and 75°, respectively, with scenes viewed horizontally from an eye height of 1.52 m. Figure 2 shows a screen shot of Store 3. (Note that the map in the upper right-hand corner was not displayed to participants in Experiment 1.)

          Enhancing Spatial Knowledge With Discrete Euclidean Virtual 3D Display Interfaces: Design Options

          https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.568853

          FIG. 2. Screenshot in Store 3 environment in black and white. Note. The map menu inset used for between-room teleportation shown in the upper right-hand corner was present only in Experiment 2. The shaded room indicated the participant's current location, and it was colored a bright yellow.

          Display full size

          FIG. 2. Screenshot in Store 3 environment in black and white. Note. The map menu inset used for between-room teleportation shown in the upper right-hand corner was present only in Experiment 2. The shaded room indicated the participant's current location, and it was colored a bright yellow.

          To travel through the 3D environment, participants used a mouse to click on the arrow icons shown in Figure 2. The up and down arrows moved the viewpoint from its current location to one location forward or one location backward, respectively. Viewpoint locations are shown as dots in Figure 1. The left and right arrows had different rotation settings for store views and hallway views. The left and right arrows turned the participants' viewpoint orientation 45° to the left and right, respectively, while inside the stores. The same left and right arrows rotated participants' viewpoint 90° to the left or right, respectively, while in the hallway. Clicking on an arrow activated a link to an HTML node that displayed the appropriate 3D perspective view. These movement operations were identical to those in the web 9–45° condition of Couture et al. (2005). Participants viewed the environments using the same equipment used by Couture et al., viewing the environments on the same 20-in. cathode ray tube monitor (41 cm × 31 cm).

          2.3. Procedure

          Scenario

          Participants were seated approximately 45 cm from the front of the computer monitor (producing screen visual angles of 49°and 38°). They first received a brief practice session in which they heard a description of the commands and instructions on how to travel through the training environment. They practiced movement control and object search by finding three colored blocks in the training environment, which consisted of one hallway and one room.

          After completing training, the training environment was closed and the shopping environment was opened. Participants were told that they were working as a part-time personal assistant to a disabled person, and they had to go on an investigative shopping trip to a local shopping center to find information about some potential purchases. A script guided consecutive object searches and provided a shopping focus. Participants began shopping at the center viewpoint location of the furniture store. They heard successive directions to visit each of the three objects in the store (nightstand, chair, and couch, in order for the first store). Participants heard the directions for the first task in the script and then were allowed to complete it (e.g., “You enter the store. The first item on the list is a nightstand, and Jim wants an oak one if possible. Go over to the nightstand and gather the information.”). Participants were told to get as close to each object as possible, and they were given information about each object after they arrived. Participants heard information such as dimensions, features, and prices. Next, participants were directed to move to the consumer electronics store and visit each of its three objects (stereo, copy machine, and television, in order). Finally, they traveled to the appliance store, gathering information about the stove, the washing machine, and the refrigerator. Once all nine objects had been visited by the participants, they were informed that their shopping was complete, and the virtual environment was shut down.

          Measures

          Three performance measures, identical to those used by Couture et al., were collected from participants after they completed the virtual environment. Participants recalled the names of the objects and completed two configural spatial knowledge measures—a pointing task and a free-hand sketch map. Pointing and map drawing order were counterbalanced across participants. Prior to performing the two spatial knowledge tasks, participants were given a free recall test to measure how well they remembered the objects in the virtual environment. Participants were asked to write down, in any order, the names of any objects they could remember from the shopping experience. Next, they either drew a sketch map of the environment or performed the pointing task. Then, the other configural knowledge task (pointing or sketch map) was completed. Finally, a self-report and rating scale form, identical to the one used by Couture et al. (2005), was completed. The form asked for demographic information and self-ratings of how much experience participants had with similar situations (i.e., online shopping, video games, etc.). In addition, 7-point ratings were obtained for six questions about the environment they experienced, such as how easy it was to locate objects located in the same or different stores and how difficult it was to keep track of where they were in the environment.

          For the pointing measure, participants used a direction circle presented on a laptop computer with the screen flat on the table. Queries were presented at the top of the screen, and participants had to move an arrow around the circle to indicate the desired direction. Queries were constructed asking participants to imagine that they were in the virtual environment standing in front of and looking at an orienting object, and to point toward a target object's location by using the compass arrow on the laptop screen. An example of a query is, “You are in front of and squarely facing the refrigerator. Point to the couch.” There were 18 queries, nine within-store queries and nine between-store queries, randomly intermixed. A within-store query asked for the angle between two objects in the same store. A between-store query asked for the angle between two objects in different stores. Each of the nine objects was used once as an orienting object and once as a target object. The absolute value of the difference between the pointing responses and the actual angle between the objects in the virtual environment was calculated and used as measure of angular error (Batschelet, 1981).

          For the sketch map measure, participants drew a map of the virtual environment on a blank sheet of paper. They were given a list of all of the target object names. They were asked to include doorways, walls, and objects in their correct locations and to identify the objects by name. Participants were also instructed to indicate the front of each object using an arrow. Sketch maps were scored by using the map to answer the same queries used in the pointing task. The angle between the orienting object and the target object was measured by assuming the participant was standing in front of and facing the orienting object on the map. All queries that participants answered for the pointing task were used to collect angular data from the sketch map. Therefore, there were nine between-room angular measures and nine within-room angular measures. As before, each of the nine objects was used once as an orienting object and once as a target object. The dependent variable was the absolute value of the difference between the correct angle and the corresponding angle drawn on the map.

          2.4. Experimental Design

          The experiment was a 3 × 2 × 2 mixed factorial design, which was used to analyze both sketch map and pointing data. The between-subjects factors were environmental configuration (hallways, cluster, linear) and order of testing (map/pointing, pointing/map), and the repeated-measures factor was target object location (within-store, between-store). To address the questions described in the introduction, the environmental configuration factor was decomposed into two planned orthogonal contrasts. Contrast 1, the hallways effect, evaluated the hallway condition (hallways vs. no hallways) with the mean of the clustered and linear conditions (contrast weights were 1, –½, –½, respectively). Contrast 2, the no-hallways configuration effect, evaluated the clustered versus the linear condition (contrast weights were 0, 1, –1). The effects of these two contrasts and their interactions with the other factors were determined. A 5% level of confidence was used.

          2.5. Results

          Sketch maps

          As Figure 3 shows, the room effect was considerably greater for the hallway condition than for the two no-hallways conditions. The interaction of the hallways effect (contrast 1) with the room effect was statistically significant, F(1, 66) = 23.8, MSE = 185.91, p < .0001. For the hallway condition, angular error was 35.9° greater for between-room queries than for within-room queries. The comparable difference for the two no-hallways conditions was an increase of only 12.3°. There also was a significant main effect of hallways versus no hallways (Contrast 1), F(1, 66) = 11.2, MSE = 527.64, p = .001, which, as Figure 3 shows, appears to be a consequence of the Large Hallways × Room Effect interaction. As usual, there was also a large overall room effect (within-store vs. between-store queries), F(1, 66) = 79.5, MSE = 185.91, p < .0001. The main effect of order of testing (map/pointing, pointing/map) and all interactions with it were not statistically significant.

          Enhancing Spatial Knowledge With Discrete Euclidean Virtual 3D Display Interfaces: Design Options

          All authors
          Tiffany N. Saffell, Herbert A. Colle, Ian M. Bock & Lisa J. Douglas
          https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.568853
          Published online:
          05 December 2011

          FIG. 3. Sketch map data for within-store and between-store mean angular error (degrees) and 95% confidence intervals for hallway versus no hallway (linear, clustered) conditions in Experiment 1.

          Display full size

          FIG. 3. Sketch map data for within-store and between-store mean angular error (degrees) and 95% confidence intervals for hallway versus no hallway (linear, clustered) conditions in Experiment 1.

          Performance on the two no-hallways room configuration conditions (clustered, linear) appeared to be similar. As Figure 3 shows, the room effect increase was comparable for the linear and clustered configurations; the two within-room to between-room increases were 10.9° and 13.9°, respectively. The interaction of Contrast 2 with the room effect was not statistically significant, F(1, 66) = 0.29, MSE = 185.91, p = .624. Although it appears from Figure 3 that the clustered condition has greater angular error than the linear condition, this main effect difference (Contrast 2) was not statistically significant, F(1, 66) = 2.53, MSE = 527.64, p = .116. The error bar to the left of the data, labeled as Room Configuration, shows the 95% confidence interval for between-subjects effects, which is the confidence interval that should be used for making between-subjects comparisons (Loftus, 2002). It also shows that the clustered and linear conditions were similar, consistent with the analysis of variance (ANOVA) results. The 95% confidence intervals attached to each of the points should be used only to make repeated-measures comparisons (Loftus, 2002). These confidence intervals suggest that a room effect difference was present for both linear and clustered room configurations, although as the previous analysis showed it was smaller than the hallway room effect. The similarity of the results from the clustered and linear room configurations was further supported by analyzing the data without the hallways condition, using a typical factorial ANOVA. This produced a follow-up 2 × 2 × 2 mixed ANOVA of just the two no-hallways conditions together with test order as another between-subjects factor and the room effect (within-room, between-room) as a repeated-measures factor. The room effect was statistically significant, F(1, 44) = 22.5, MSE = 164.71, p < .0001, but there was no interaction with no-hallways room configuration (clustered, linear), F(1, 44) = 0.332, MSE = 164.71, p = .57, and no main effect of room configuration, F(1, 44) = 2.35, MSE = 567.74, p = .13.

          Pointing

          The results using the pointing measure as a dependent variable were similar to those found using sketch maps. As Figure 4 shows, the room effect again was considerably greater for the hallway condition than for the two no-hallways conditions. The interaction of the hallways effect (Contrast 1) with the room effect was statistically significant, F(1, 66) = 34.26, MSE = 262.58, p < .0001. For the hallway condition, angular error was 42.19° greater for between-room queries than for within-room queries. The comparable difference for the two no-hallways conditions was an increase of only 8.59°. There also was a significant main effect of hallways versus no hallways (Contrast 1), F(1, 66) = 4.85, MSE = 914.72, p = .03, which, as Figure 4 shows, appears to be a consequence of the Large Hallways × Room Effect interaction. As usual, there was also a large overall room effect (within-store vs. between-store queries), F(1, 66) = 53.6, MSE = 262.58, p < .0001. The main effect of order of testing (map/pointing, pointing/map) and all related interactions were not statistically significant.

          Enhancing Spatial Knowledge With Discrete Euclidean Virtual 3D Display Interfaces: Design Options

          All authors
          Tiffany N. Saffell, Herbert A. Colle, Ian M. Bock & Lisa J. Douglas
          https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.568853
          Published online:
          05 December 2011

          FIG. 4. Pointing data for within-store and between-store mean angular error (degrees) and 95% confidence intervals for hallway versus no hallway (linear, clustered) conditions in Experiment 1.

          Display full size

          FIG. 4. Pointing data for within-store and between-store mean angular error (degrees) and 95% confidence intervals for hallway versus no hallway (linear, clustered) conditions in Experiment 1.

          Performance on the two no-hallways room configuration conditions (clustered, linear) appeared to be similar. As Figure 4 shows, the room effect increase was comparable for the linear and clustered configurations; the two within-room to between-room increases were 12.32° and 4.86°, respectively. The interaction of Contrast 2 with the room effect was not statistically significant, F(1, 66) = 1.27, MSE = 262.58, p = .264. Also, the Contrast 2 main effect was not significant, F(1, 66) = .001, MSE = 914.72, p = .97. A follow-up 2 × 2 × 2 mixed ANOVA of just these two no-hallways conditions together with test order as another between-subjects factor and the room effect (within-room, between-room) as a repeated-measures factor was conducted. The room effect was statistically significant, F(1, 44) = 8.09, MSE = 219.06, p = .007, but there was no interaction with no-hallways room configuration (clustered, linear), F(1, 44) = 1.52, MSE = 219.06, p = .22, and no main effect of room configuration, F(1, 44) = .001, MSE = 1143.67, p = .97.

          Subjective report

          Six items on the posttest questionnaire asked participants to rate the environment and their performance in it. Rating data were analyzed using ANOVAs because more specialized techniques are unnecessary when the number of rating categories is greater than 5 and the sample size is greater than 20 (Penfield, 2003).

          In two rating scale questions, participants were asked to rate how difficult it was to locate objects between rooms and within rooms. For example, for the between-room question participants were asked, “How easy was it to know where two objects were located, when they were in different stores?” Participants indicated their difficulty level on a 7-point scale from 1 (difficult to locate) to 7 (easy to locate). The same question was asked for two objects located in the same store.

          These two rating questions were analyzed together using a 3 × 2 × 2 mixed ANOVA. Once again, the between-subjects factors were the two contrasts on the environmental configuration (hallways, cluster, linear) and order of testing (map/pointing, pointing/map). The repeated-measures factor was the room effect (between-store, within-store). Overall, participants subjectively rated between-store judgments as more difficult than within-store judgments, F(1, 65) = 39.03, MSE = 1.519, p < .0001. Participants' mean ratings were 3.57 for between-store judgments compared to 4.86 for within-store judgments. This room effect did not interact with any other factors or contrasts. One participant was excluded from this ANOVA because he failed to include a between-store rating.

          The other four subjective rating questions were analyzed using only the between-subjects contrasts on environmental configuration and order of testing. There were no main effects or interactions for any of these subjective ratings questions.

          Free recall

          The number correctly recalled on the free recall test was analyzed. Participants in the linear and clustered conditions recalled 0.40 more objects than those in the hallway condition, 8.52 objects versus 8.12 objects, respectively. The hallway effect was significant (Contrast 1), F(1, 66) = 4.3, MSE = 0.58, p = .04. The linear and the cluster conditions (no hallways, Contrast 2) were not significantly different, F(1, 66) = 1.75, MSE = 0.58, p = .19. There was also no order effect, F(1, 66) = 0, MSE = 0.58, p = 1. Furthermore, there was no interaction between order and contrast 1, F(1, 66) = 0.96, MSE = 0.58, p = .33, or between order and Contrast 2, F(1, 66), MSE = 0.96, p = .34. Analyses of the number of intrusions and the number of runs (with objects categorized by stores) found no significant effects. The overall mean number of runs of was 3.87. The overall mean number of intrusions was 0.15.

          2.6. Discussion

          Configural spatial knowledge measures obtained from both sketch maps and pointing measures produced similar results. Clearly, participants had more between-store spatial knowledge of the location of objects when they could travel from store to store directly without having to exit a store into a hallway to travel to the next store. These results suggest that environmental designs should minimize the use of hallways to travel between stores, especially if a complicated hallway structure is required. In the present study, stores in the hallway condition also were more distant from each other, so it could be argued that travel distance contributed to this effect. However, Colle and Reid (1998, 2003) clearly showed that distance between rooms is not a good predictor of between-room spatial knowledge. Therefore, it is more likely that, as they argued, other factors such as the ability to integrate structural frames of reference are responsible for the effect. Hallway complexity is a factor, but recently Douglas, Colle, Reid, and Saffell (2011) manipulated the complexity of hallway structure and found that even relatively simple hallways can cause problems.

          The results also clearly indicate that between-store spatial knowledge was similar for linear and clustered configurations of rooms, when participants did not have to use hallways to travel from store to store. Therefore, design of room configurations does not have to be limited to linear structures in order to produce good spatial knowledge of the total environment, as Robertson et al. (2000) suggested. However, the results were found only for a limited number of stores.

          3. EXPERIMENT 2

          Given that traversing hallways is likely to hamper the acquisition of between-store spatial knowledge and that there may be limitations on the effectiveness of configurations with increasing numbers of stores, another design option for moving from one store to another was explored in Experiment 2. Teleportation has been considered as a means for traveling between two rooms (Bakker et al., 2003; Couture et al., 2005; Ruddle et al., 2000) where movement can be instantaneous regardless of distance and traveling more pleasant by reducing long treks (Hedman, 2003; Helander, 2000).

          However, teleportation can hamper spatial knowledge acquisition. In Couture et al.'s Web 1–90° condition with the hallways layout used in Experiment 1, participants were teleported from store to store with a single click. Their between-store spatial knowledge was at the chance level, which was not surprising because they were not given any information about the store locations to which they were teleported. Within-store HTML rotations and translations are a form of teleportation, which retain good spatial knowledge acquisition, as Couture et al. (2005) have shown. Between-room teleportation can be less disruptive if it is used to go from directly connected rooms, but it is much more disruptive when long jumps across several rooms are taken (Ruddle et al., 2000). Bakker et al. (2003) provided teleportation guidance by verbally providing participants with the room number and the wall they would be facing before they were teleported to the test location. People took longer to respond to pointing queries in the teleport condition compared to a nonteleport condition in which participants were moved through the hallways to the test location. The goal of teleportation is twofold: make travel easy and efficient while facilitating spatial knowledge acquisition. The problem, then, is determining how to teleport people to distant rooms while maintaining the support needed to successfully acquire spatial knowledge about the environment.

          To facilitate overall spatial knowledge while teleporting, we attempted to integrate an environmental map into the teleportation commands. Using a map to control movement has been suggested by both Darken and Peterson (2002) and by Jones and Goldiez (2004), but neither empirically tested their proposals. In previous research, teleportation was activated by clicking on a doorway, which moved participants an unknown direction and distance to another room (Ruddle et al., 2000) or used verbal information regarding the destination room and the facing direction. In contrast, participants in the current study teleported by using a map menu. The map menu is shown in the upper right-hand corner of Figure 2. The map menu depicts the structural layout of all of the stores in the environment, showing their doorways and the hallways between them. Participants would teleport by clicking on one of the stores, which would instantly move them to the doorway of that store. Thus, the map provided plan view global information as well as global destination information. If participants can integrate this plan view information with the local perspective information about objects inside of the stores, then they should acquire good spatial knowledge. This design is consistent with the results of Ruddle, Payne, and Jones (1999), who found that after participants gained experience with an environment, global maps alone were effective and local maps did not add much spatial knowledge. However, in their research the task was searching in an unstructured virtual seascape environment, and their maps were used to guide movement, not to teleport between locations. Similarly, inset maps used as wayfinding tools, have facilitated search task performance (time to find targets and success percentage) when they provided an environmental overview during navigation of perspective view virtual environments of cities (Wu, Zhang, & Zhang, 2009). Lee et al. (2007) described using a map interface that controlled the local movements of robots in an indoor physical space by selecting target goal locations on a map interface.

          In this experiment, the map menu teleportation condition was compared with the hallway travel condition used in Experiment 1 to see if it was as good as, better than, or worse than hallway travel. The focus here is on between-store spatial knowledge because both conditions would be exposed to the same within-room information. Specifically we are interested in the interaction of the room effect with the two different types of movement conditions.

          3.1. Method

          Experiment 2 replicated the hallways condition of Experiment 1 in the same environment using the same procedure. It compared this hallways condition to a map menu teleportation condition. Participants traveled either by moving through hallways or by teleporting via the map menu icon. When hallways were used, participants traveled from store to store using the interconnecting hallways, as in Experiment 1. In map menu teleportation, participants were not allowed to travel using the hallways; they clicked on a store on the map menu icon in the top right-hand corner of each web page, as shown in Figure 2. They were then teleported to the doorway of that store, facing inside of the room. The current store location was always highlighted in yellow. The door was also indicated on the map menu. The map menu icon in the upper right-hand corner of Figure 2 shows the layout of the entire environment. The map menu and its operation were explained to participants in the map menu condition. In both conditions, the layout was identical to the hallways condition used in Experiment 1 and in Couture et al. (2005). All other methodological and procedural conditions were the same, except the pointing task and sketch map drawing were not counterbalanced. Participants always performed the pointing task before drawing their sketch maps.

          Participants (N = 48) with normal or corrected-to-normal vision from introductory psychology courses were randomly assigned to the hallway or map menu teleportation conditions. Of all participants, 16 were male and 32 were female with a mean age of 19.9, ranging from 18 to 37.

          3.2. Results

          A 2 × 2 mixed ANOVA was used to analyze the absolute angular error data for both sketch maps and pointing data. The between-subjects factor was mode of travel (hallway use, map menu teleportation), and the repeated-measures factor was target object location (the room effect: within-store, between-store). A 5% confidence level was used.

          Sketch maps

          Figure 5 shows the within-store and between-store mean absolute angular error in sketch maps for both hallway and map menu teleportation conditions. Although Figure 5 suggests that the room effect was larger when participants traveled from store to store using hallways than it was when participants used map menu teleportation, the interaction of travel mode with the room effect (within-store, between-store) was not statistically significant at the 5% level of confidence, F(1, 46) = 2.67, MSE = 386, p = .11. Within-store to between-store absolute angular error increased 38.7° for participants who traversed hallways, and it increased 25.6° for participants who used map menu teleportation. As mentioned previously, the store configuration confidence interval, not the confidence interval about the points, should be used for directly comparing between-subjects effects. The 95% confidence interval for the interaction difference was 16.1°, which is larger than the observed mean interaction difference of 13.1°. The main effect of travel mode also was not statistically significant, F(1, 46) = 3.53, MSE = 737, p = .07. As expected, there was a large room effect, F(1, 46) = 64.4, MSE = 386, p < .0001. Mean within-store angular error was only 27.9° compared to a between-store angular error of 60.1°.

          Enhancing Spatial Knowledge With Discrete Euclidean Virtual 3D Display Interfaces: Design Options

          All authors
          Tiffany N. Saffell, Herbert A. Colle, Ian M. Bock & Lisa J. Douglas
          https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.568853
          Published online:
          05 December 2011

          FIG. 5. Sketch map data for within-store and between-store mean angular error (degrees) and 95% confidence intervals for hallway versus map menu conditions in Experiment 2.

          Display full size

          FIG. 5. Sketch map data for within-store and between-store mean angular error (degrees) and 95% confidence intervals for hallway versus map menu conditions in Experiment 2.

          Pointing

          Absolute angular pointing error was analyzed using the same 2 × 2 ANOVA used with sketch map data. Pointing error means are shown in Figure 6. The interaction of travel mode with the room effect was not statistically significant, F(1, 46) = 3.82, MSE = 449, p = .06. The room effect (within-store vs. between-store) increased 29.3° for participants who traversed hallways, and it increased 46.2° for participants who used map menu teleportation. The 95% confidence interval for the interaction difference was 20.0°, which is larger than the observed mean interaction difference of 16.9°. The main effect of travel mode also was not significant, F(1, 46) = 0.062, MSE = 486, p = .80. Again, as expected, there was a large room effect (within-store vs. between-store), F(1, 46) = 76.3, MSE = 449, p < .0001. Angular error for within-store queries (M = 49.4°) was much smaller than for between-store queries (M = 87.1°).

          Enhancing Spatial Knowledge With Discrete Euclidean Virtual 3D Display Interfaces: Design Options

          All authors
          Tiffany N. Saffell, Herbert A. Colle, Ian M. Bock & Lisa J. Douglas
          https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.568853
          Published online:
          05 December 2011

          FIG. 6. Pointing data for within-store and between-store mean angular error (degrees) and 95% confidence intervals for hallway versus map menu conditions in Experiment 2.

          Display full size

          FIG. 6. Pointing data for within-store and between-store mean angular error (degrees) and 95% confidence intervals for hallway versus map menu conditions in Experiment 2.

          Subjective report

          Subjective rating of difficulty agreed with the two performance measures. Participants rated how easy it was to know where objects were located when they were in the same store or in different stores. A 2 × 2 mixed ANOVA was again used to analyze these data. Mean within-store rating of spatial knowledge (1 = very difficult, 7 = very easy) was 4.79 compared with a between-store rating of 3.25, F(1, 46) = 46.9, MSE = 1.22, p < .0001. However, it did not interact with travel mode, and the main effect of travel mode was not significant, F(1, 46) = 0.00, MSE = 1.21, p = 1.0, and F(1, 46) = 0.22, MSE = 2.92, p = .64, respectively.

          Participants who used the map menu did report having less difficulty keeping track of where they were in the environment, F(1, 46) = 4.51, MSE = 1.67, p = .039. Mean rating for map menu teleportation was 2.29 compared with a rating of 3.08 for hallway movement (1 = no trouble, 7 = very much trouble). None of the effects were significant for the other rating questions.

          3.3. Discussion

          Similar results were found for both sketch maps and pointing data. In both measures, map menu teleportation did not degrade the acquisition of configural spatial knowledge, and the results of this experiment suggest that this type of teleportation could be incorporated into the design of 3D perspective virtual interfaces without degrading configural spatial knowledge acquisition of the environment.

          On the other hand, the data suggested that map menu teleportation did not improve between-store spatial knowledge acquisition compared with traveling from store to store via hallways. Experiments 1 and 2, along with previously published research (Colle & Reid, 1998, 2000, 2003; Couture et al., 2005), have found that within-store spatial knowledge was more accurate than between-store spatial knowledge when hallways are used to travel from store to store (or room to room). It would be desirable to develop a between-store mode of travel that could improve between-store spatial knowledge so that it is comparable to within-store spatial knowledge. Experiment 1 showed that comparable between-store and within-store spatial knowledge is achievable by allowing direct travel from store to store without using hallways. Between-store spatial knowledge acquisition was comparable to within-store spatial knowledge acquisition when stores were adjacent and participants could move directly from store-to-store without using a hallway. Therefore, between-store spatial knowledge acquisition is not inherently less accurate than within-store spatial knowledge acquisition. However, having only adjacent stores limits the size of environments. Alternative between-store modes of travel need to be examined to determine the feasibility of making between-store and within-store spatial knowledge comparable.

          One design approach would be to follow up the partial success of the map menu teleportation technique by examining alternative implementations of map menu teleportation techniques with a goal of improving between-store spatial knowledge acquisition. Experiment 2 used only one of several different map menu teleportation options. The basic design principle is to have participants use a two-dimensional spatial plan view map to select a destination so that they can gain map knowledge of the global environment as an inherent part of their between-store spatial knowledge acquisition. In Experiment 2, participants could select a new store from the map menu when they were in any location in any store facing any direction. When a new store was selected, the participant was teleported instantly to the doorway of a new store, facing into that store as if he or she were walking in. We thought that this was natural when traveling from store to store, and it made available structural information about the participant's location in the new store. Participants could see that they were in the doorway, a recognizable room component. However, it also produced potentially confusing orientation transformations because the direction they were facing after teleportation was irrelevant to the direction they had been facing before teleportation. The only way they could know the direction of the target room and the direction they were facing was if they encoded the relative positions of the two stores and could integrate this with the spatial location of objects in both stores, which were not graphically represented in the map menu. This may have been difficult, given that the instructions focused participants' attention on shopping, not on learning the environment.

          Bakker et al. (2003) found evidence that the amount of rotation during a teleportation displacement affected spatial knowledge performance. Plan view maps also have been found to be difficult for people to interpret when map orientation does not agree with a person's current orientation in a geometric space (Levine, 1982; Levine, Marchon, & Hanley, 1984). Displacement rules could be used to help minimize the confusion of orientation transformations. For example, when participants selected a store from the map menu, they could be rotated automatically using the typical rotation steps until they faced the direction of the selected store and then teleported. Although the acquisition of spatial knowledge (a) by studying plan view maps and (b) by directly interacting with an environment with perspective viewing both have been studied, they appear to generate different types of configural spatial knowledge (Thorndyke & Hayes-Roth, 1982). It is still not clear how spatial memory representation obtained from these two different types of acquisition experiences differ and how they can be integrated.

          4. DESIGN IMPLICATIONS

          Although the current research focused on the specific task domain of online or web-based shopping (Miles, Howes, & Davies, 2000), Euclidean 3D spatial interfaces have a wider range of potential applications. Designs can build on the three major results of the present and past experiments.

          First, the room effect implies that data content should be correlated with spatial structure, as it is in most physical shopping environments. This is a broader principle than just relying on single room geometry because the room effect data imply that people quickly learn the spatial relations of objects in several rooms, simultaneously holding the layouts in memory. Thus, the relative locations of several clusters of data types can be found quickly and interrelated easily when a cluster is colocated in a room. Users should have a mental model of the main features of the data structure in order to take advantage of the content to spatial structure mappings (Chen, 1998; Stanney et al., 2003). The present results show, however, inexperienced users or “visitors” (Hedman, 2003) can develop the relevant mental model and gain the performance benefits. Even though objects of the same data type seem to benefit from clustered spatial arrangements, data clusters probably are inappropriate for keeping track of a set of acquired documents, such as those found from an online search (Robertson et al., 2000). On the other hand, to take advantage of spatial-to-content mapping, users or visitors need to be able to acquire the appropriate spatial memory representations. However, some patients with brain damage may not benefit from discrete spatial interfaces if their spatial memory processes or representations are impaired. For example, patients with vestibular function loss have been found to have difficulty acquiring complex spatial information when restricted only to visually presented information (Borel, Lopez, Péruch, & Lacour, 2008). Patients who do not generate vestibular cues appear impaired in their ability to generate accurate spatial representations even when tasks such as those on desktop virtual environments do not provide and do not require the use of vestibular or somatosensory cues.

          The second design implication is the importance of between-room spatial structure. As Experiment 1 showed, larger clusters of data types can be cross-located by using multiple rooms that are adjacent to each other. Compact adjacent spaces not only improve between-room spatial knowledge acquisition but are easier to travel from location to location. However, the present data studied only sets of three rooms, and therefore the maximum number of adjacent rooms that will still show the spatial knowledge advantage has not been established.

          Finally, the third design implication suggested by the data is that teleportation can be added to Euclidean 3D spatial interfaces without losing knowledge of relevant spatial locations as long as teleportation is not blind or unguided. Guiding teleportation by using map menus appeared to be feasible. This study focused on a virtual shopping environment that reflected the structure of a physical shopping space, allowing participants to travel using teleportation or hallways. Also, the current research only evaluated single floor structures. Spatial environment and travel metaphors could include multiple floor structures by using multifloor maps (Chittaro & Venkataraman, 2006) or virtual escalators (J. Kim, 1999). In other domains, map menu teleportation may be used to explore and learn hotel facilities and home layouts and furnishings. In these cases, users can dynamically explore and learn the locations and designs of critical items both within and between rooms (e.g., http://www.visualtour.com, http://www.realtourvision.com/) before booking a room or deciding to pursue a home purchase.

          The map menu teleportation results and room structure importance may also be useful for military domains such as the teleoperation of unmanned ground vehicles (UGVs). For example, a map menu has been used successfully to provide a goal location to which a robot would move; however, all locations were in a single room (Lee et al., 2007). Operators of UGVs get spatially disoriented, but the addition of plan view maps did improve overall spatial knowledge acquisition (Chadwick, 2005). However, perceived physical location obtained from the UGV operator's point-of-view screen did not correspond fully with its location in concurrent plan view maps, depending on the relative orientation of the plan view maps (Chadwick & Pazuchanics, 2007). The problem of map and viewpoint correspondences was discussed previously, however not specifically in the context of teleoperation. One solution is to use map menu control as Lee et al. (2007) did with their robot, when this is possible. Alternative solutions to the spatial disorientation of UGV operators could be solved by imposing a virtual room including virtual walls on the UGV operator's perspective display screen such as Brandtberg and Alfredson (1999) did with their head-down manned aircraft tactical situation display, providing operators with orienting structure and landmarks. Because individuals could teleport in the current study without a loss of spatial knowledge acquisition, this also suggests that UGV controllers could switch from one UGV viewpoint to another UGV viewpoint without a loss of spatial knowledge as long as a map or map menu is present to represent the UGV positions.

          Acknowledgments

          We thank Jerritte Couture for his help with creating the HTML environments, and Alicia Tassos, Adam Moeller, Bradley Beck, and Christa Brown for help with testing participants, data coding, and analyzing data.
